EXECUTIVE SUMMARY BAYER MATERIALSCIENCE LLC
NEW MARTINSVILLE PLANT

December 17, 2007

Executive Summary for the Risk Management Rule

1.  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
Bayer MaterialScience LLC is committed to the principles of Responsible Care which emphasize operating in a safe and environmentally correct manner. Management systems are in place to assure all facilities are complying with these principles.  There are Corporate Engineering Standards and Health, Environment and Safety Guidelines which address every aspect of Risk Management from the design of intrinsically safe processes, to the use of risk assessment, to incident tracking and program audits. Bayer MaterialScience LLC is a Bayer AG company, which is headquartered in Leverkusen, Germany.  Bayer MaterialScience LLC has its own company structure, policies and procedures which are consistent with those of the holding company, but are customized to meet local regulations and standards.  Bayer AG has established guidelines for Responsible Care in Environmental Protection and Safety, which include a Directive for Process and Plant Safety that all Bayer facilities world-wide are expected to follow.  It provides guidance for safe process design and operation.

In the US, Bayer MaterialScience LLC is an active member of the American Chemistry Council's Responsible Care Initiative.  Bayer has implemented all seven codes of management practice.  Bayer MaterialScience LLC has a Health, Safety, Environment and Quality Policy which states that it is the company?s responsibility to protect the environment and the health and safety of its employees, customers and communities.  This is a primary responsibility, of equal importance to any other business objective.  This is supported in the Bayer MaterialScience LLC Visions, Values and Beliefs, which emphasize applying technical expertise to advance our business while assuring the safety and protection of our employees, customers, commun

ities and the environment.

The Bayer MaterialScience LLC New Martinsville facility has implemented all of the corporate Health Environment and Safety Policies and Guidelines through site policies and procedures.  These include site Safety and Health Procedures, Emergency Response Procedures, Process Safety Management Procedures, Hazard Communication Procedures and Risk Management Procedures as well as safety plans in the individual production unit SOPs.  The Bayer MaterialScience LLC New Martinsville facility is a VPP Star site and is RC/ISO 14001 certified. 

In addition, the Bayer MaterialScience LLC, New Martinsville facility uses the following measures to assure the safety of our chemical processes:

? Special equipment standards
? Special flanges, piping, valves
? Remotely operated isolation valves
? State of the art computerized controls

? Dikes and curbs to contain spills 
? Vacuum system for equipment preparation
? Spot ventilation system
? Continuous process analyzers
? Production units designed to withstand natural disasters
? Active ethylene oxide safety panel (ACC)

program

2.  Facility Description and Regulated Substances Handled
The primary activities at the New Martinsville facility are towards the manufacture of polyurethane intermediates, coatings intermediates and thermoplastics.  Products include polyethers, prepolymers, polyesters and aspartic esters. In addition aromatic isocyanates, toluene diisocyanate and polymeric diphenylmethane diisocyanate are received for reprocessing and repackaging.  The New Martinsville facility uses or stores four of the RMP listed chemicals on the site as of December 17, 2007.  Of the four chemicals covered, three are raw materials and one is a finished product.  All four chemicals were modeled using worst case release parameters as a screening exercise to determine the worst case scenario for the facility.  The New Martinsville site MR-I Phosgenation Process, Methylene Dianiline Process and Chlorine Pipeline were shut down in 2007.  The MR-I Phosgenation Process was the location of the worst case and alternative scenarios for phosgene and the alternative scenario for ammonia.  The new worst case scenario chem

ical for the New Martinsville site is ethylene oxide.  The alternative scenarios in order of potential off-site impact are ethylene oxide, toluene diisocyanate, propylene oxide and ethylene diamine.

3.  Worst Case Scenario for the Facility
The worst case release scenario for the New Martinsville facility is the rupture of the ethylene oxide storage tank.  Because of the low storage temperature, the release to the atmosphere occurs through evaporation from a pool.   Through use of dispersion modeling (PHAST software), the endpoint distance reaches offsite receptors. This release assumes no mitigation other than containment in a dike.

4.  Alternative Release Scenarios
Alternative scenarios were developed for all of the RMP chemicals. The alternative scenario for ethylene oxide has the largest potential impact distance of the group. In this scenario it is assumed that a leak develops during the unloading of a rail car.  Under typical weather conditions as suggested in the RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance the distance to the endpoint reaches offsite receptors.

5.  Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
The New Martinsville Plant complies with all elements of the OSHA PSM Rule and the EPA RMP Rule.  There are safety procedures, standard operation emergency procedures, accident investigations, hot work and line opening permits, extensive training programs, on-site emergency response teams, vessel inspection programs, and experienced personnel both in the salaried and hourly workforce.  Bayer MaterialScience LLC is an active member of the ACC Ethylene Oxide Safety Panel that deals with ethylene oxide safety issues on an industry-wide basis.

6.  Five Year Accident History
There have been no releases in the past five years that had off-site consequences.  A liquid TDI release within the plant resulted in an OSHA Recordable Accident in 2007.  The release totaled 10 pounds.  At the New Martinsville facility, there has never be

en any offsite impact resulting from the release of chemicals listed in the rule. 

7.  Facility Emergency Response Program
The New Martinsville facility Emergency Response System consists of volunteer emergency response teams scheduled on each rotating shift.  There are 185 emergency response team members.  They receive 16 to 50 hours of on-site training annually with some disciplines receiving off-site training as well in specialized subjects, such as fire fighting, rescue, incident command and Hazmat.  An E-Team organization provides secondary support and is staffed by Technical and Managerial Personnel.  The E-Team's main function is to assist and advise the Emergency Response Teams and communicate with outside agencies.  The plant belongs to an industrial mutual aid group called NORIMAC (Northern Ohio River Industrial Mutual Aid Council) that provides mutual aid between the various industries, government agencies, and service organizations in the area.  Community warning sirens are placed in residential areas within 2 miles of the plant and have been in operation, as part of the CAER program, for more than twenty years.
